text:
<@U01NW9AE6CV> Actually, it's doable to rank for that keyword but as <@U013W748P7T> said, you can't do it with a single article.

How I'd do it:

1. Create the page for "best business credit cards for startups". Create it in the way the audience expects it. Listicles in the SERP? Do a listicle, but better. Optimize it well. 
2. Create a cluster of relevant articles on the subject. Interlink everything in the cluster. 
3. Get backlinks for the "pillar" on the exact anchor "best business credit cards for startups". 
4. Get backlinks for the other articles in the cluster as well.
5. Soon, you'll see your whole cluster grow like this: <https://i.imgur.com/RtnaQAQ.png> Yaay, you've got topical authority now. 
The method is tried and tested. I managed to rank a client's landing page higher than the behemoths that were dominating the SERP (DR 88, 89, 91) while my client has DR 76 (DA 41). I also did it several times so it's not a one time thing. It's also nothing new.

I hope this helps.

Soon, you'll see your whole cluster grow like this:

The method is tried and tested. I managed to rank a client's landing page higher than the behemoths that were dominating the SERP (DR 88, 89, 91) while my client has DR 76 (DA 41). I also did it several times so it's not a one time thing. It's also nothing new.

I hope this helps.

text: Wow, super helpful thank you <@U02HYFGDTQW>. I've always been more of a long tail keyword strategist than pillar page, but I feel that for this one I need to take it to another level. Do you know how long it took you to put this all together? I'm a one person content marketing team so I feel it'll take me a while...

elements.text: Wow, super helpful thank you

. I've always been more of a long tail keyword strategist than pillar page, but I feel that for this one I need to take it to another level. Do you know how long it took you to put this all together? I'm a one person content marketing team so I feel it'll take me a while...

text:
Can't say for sure how much it would take one person to do it because I have a whole team handling various parts of the content marketing process.

My advice is to outsource whenever you can and focus only on what you do best.

For us, this process is standard and we do it on a regular basis.

How much it takes will depend on how well you optimize your process.

text: Agency partner here, chiming in to agree with <@U024K88ECFN>. It's much easier to adjust one agency's work for two audiences than it is to coordinate the work of two agencies. You gain a lot of efficiency and shorten learning curves by using one agency, IMO.

elements.text: Agency partner here, chiming in to agree with
. It's much easier to adjust one agency's work for two audiences than it is to coordinate the work of two agencies. You gain a lot of efficiency and shorten learning curves by using one agency, IMO.

Any additional thoughts on agency vs. hiring?

text:
Been using the free version of Trell to manage the workflow, but it's not cutting it anymore with the size of our team. We're planning to switch to ClickUp. I haven't used it before so can't vouch for it, but another team at our company does and from what I've seen playing around with a test account, it's gonna be waaay better than what we have. It does a good job of centralizing things. Right now, we're bouncing between Trello, G suite, G chat/Slack, it's pretty messy TBH :grimacing:

To the last part of your question, I've been documenting a lot of things this year as our team has grown. I'm still trying to find the balance of making sure things are followed correctly, let me know if you have any lightbulb moments :joy: One thing I've heard/seen is making the information as quick and easy to access as possible. One example is putting checklists on the Trello card (rather than in a separate doc) and creating template cards with links to all the relevant resources for the type of content a writer will be working on. That way they don't have to dig through Drive to find what they need. Then it's a simple matter of them duplicating the card or copying the info to an existing one if they're coming back for a 2nd pass on something. Not foolproof but it's definitely helped.

One thing I've heard/seen is making the information as quick and easy to access as possible. One example is putting checklists on the Trello card (rather than in a separate doc) and creating template cards with links to all the relevant resources for the type of content a writer will be working on. That way they don't have to dig through Drive to find what they need. Then it's a simple matter of them duplicating the card or copying the info to an existing one if they're coming back for a 2nd pass on something. Not foolproof but it's definitely helped.

text: I was curious about the choice to keep SEO and content separate. I know some agencies aren't set up to do both well, but again we've run into issues before trying to separate these with another agency. What's your thought process there? (Not saying it's necessarily bad; I was just wondering.)

elements.text: I was curious about the choice to keep SEO and content separate. I know some agencies aren't set up to do both well, but again we've run into issues before trying to separate these with another agency. What's your thought process there? (Not saying it's necessarily bad; I was just wondering.)

text:
We seperate this problem into two buckets:
• Recording processes and SOPs
• Management of processes to be untertaken
Recording processes happens within Notion. We have a set template on how to record an SOP, and operate a 'document first' approach to all of our systems. This means that if you come to perform a process and the SOP is either missing, inaccurate or simply wrong it needs to be updated/recorded. This feels suuuper slow to those recording the process for the first time, but allows us to move at serious speed later down the road.

With regard to management of tasks in a project managemnt tool we have used and worked with clients who use many different offerings. Whether it's Monday, Asana, Trello, Jira, Clickup or something custom (like in our case), really they are all different takes on the same thing and are terrible at recording proceses but great at managing them.

Here's an outtake from our handbook which may shed some more light on this for you:
```## Setting the example

Each week we consult with founders of companies who are struggling to understand, define and document their processes. It's slowing them down and restricting their growth.

Via our consulting efforts clients begin to build a solid layer of processes underneath their company,  process by process, brick by brick, eventually forming a strong foundation. This is how over the longterm large corporations are built.

Lolly Co is no different, like our clients we must be wary of individually creating processes and storing them mentally, rather than recording and documenting them. We forget things, and our memory becomes unclear. Worse we deviate, each performing the process differently attempting to build a company foundation with no clear construction plan.

Instead, together as a team we're going to set the best example possible, documenting our processes, sharing them with others, and building solid company foundations.```

Instead, together as a team we're going to set the best example possible, documenting our processes, sharing them with others, and building solid company foundations.
